E362E66A5935485D9596D5BD205BAA63.description: Answer a given question, using a given graph in which data is displayed using many-to-one correspondence.

D0714D74D73F4348A0CED0A87FD243A4.description: Create and label (with axes and title) a bar graph to display a given set of data, using many-to- one correspondence, and justify the choice of interval used.

33AA8A85C17B462EA6EDF6C047510BF3.description: Create and label (with categories, title, and legend) a pictograph to display a given set of data, using many-to-one correspondence, and justify the choice of correspondence used.

CE83D60BB09D4F6F841A59F78864590E.description: Identify an interval and correspondence for displaying a given set of data in a graph, and justify the choice.

CC53CB4287F3423A88941B13A552AB30.description: Students will be expected to construct and interpret pictographs and bar graphs involving many- to-one correspondence to draw conclusions. [C, PS, R, V]

BD9A097E8A3C4A60BE665C76AB0C4BD1.description: Find examples of graphs in print and electronic media, such as newspapers, magazines, and the Internet, in which many-to-one correspondence is used; and describe the correspondence used.

9EFCABC34D96426FBB51A4E555AB3EE3.description: Explain why many-to-one correspondence is sometimes used rather than one-to-one correspondence.

3F82BC785272448AA5A5AF3F1FC34709.description: Compare graphs in which the same data has been displayed using one-to-one and many-to- one correspondences, and explain how they are the same and different.

458B6B9B02784E12BA1DFC6A987DC4FC.description: Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of many-to-one correspondence. [C, R, T, V]

39399F48834F447CA45B5BA7934E2966.description: Explain connections between congruence and symmetry using 2-D shapes.

7267EBF4578D4F1780EAF05FCFD0F859.description: Sort a given set of 2-D shapes as those that have no lines of symmetry, one line of symmetry, or more than one line of symmetry.

DCD3E1D387E547A3B4FF2F9B6637A279.description: Provide examples of symmetrical shapes found in the environment, and identify the line(s) of symmetry.

8FF9D4B028364168B688ACE479E93759.description: Create a symmetrical shape with and without manipulatives and explain the process.

A250982948E64A159731196B98A5CC34.description: Determine whether or not a given 2-D shape is symmetrical by using an image reflector or by folding and superimposing.

02EA44D1FA8C43FAB1D268FB629C69AF.description: Identify lines of symmetry of a given set of 2-D shapes, and explain why each shape is symmetrical.

C30654ED13F44B5993B31F286A5A8CFF.description: Complete a symmetrical 2-D shape, given one-half the shape and its line of symmetry, and explain the process.

657F328FE454400D82AAC0730D7D7B6B.description: Sort a given set of 2-D shapes as symmetrical and non-symmetrical.

59A124A0E74447A0BC9BDFCE773BB8BA.description: Identify the characteristics of given symmetrical and non-symmetrical 2-D shapes.

F9F1E1D5C3FF4694BA78AF8056322499.description:
Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of line symmetry by
identifying symmetrical 2-D shapes
creating symmetrical 2-D shapes
drawing one or more lines of symmetry in a 2-D shape [C, CN, V]

D380438398FA4D3B8F5091D213E3596F.description: Identify congruent 2-D shapes from a given set of shapes shown in different positions in space.

9C5FDD97B9414861B60D219DE3976E33.description: Create a shape that is congruent to a given 2-D shape, and explain why the two shapes are congruent.

F92C72AAC60D4CBF909B429F8E5869D1.description: Determine if two given 2-D shapes are congruent, and explain the strategy used.

5615B9501A1C4993B525ADBBAECDAC69.description: Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of congruency, concretely and pictorially. [CN, R, V]

C982920BBB34495CA6B0354A8E54B157.description: Identify examples of rectangular and triangular prisms found in the environment.

18A5E571F61F4C36ABB3896212AA3445.description: Construct triangular prisms from their nets.

FC8A6F71204B4C8B80BEDA8C6F3AF68B.description: Construct rectangular prisms from their nets.

762749AEBC4E41B19AE06FA2B9FDACD5.description: Construct and describe a model of a rectangular and a triangular prism, using materials such as pattern blocks or modelling clay.

7E1AE1B3E44643F0B586C0063678B8BC.description: Sort a given set of right rectangular and triangular prisms, using the shape of the base.

1B43CCE389BB4030BA5DC96DEB430F96.description: Identify and name common attributes of triangular prisms from given sets of triangular prisms.

439204EEE04341219EFED1594ACD6B61.description: Identify and name common attributes of rectangular prisms from given sets of rectangular prisms.

1305317F46044DEDB8EF18B9242051EA.description: Students will be expected to describe and construct rectangular and triangular prisms. [C, CN, R, V]

64978396505542F7BD8EAFD47B7D8439.description: Demonstrate that many rectangles are possible for a given area by drawing at least two different rectangles for the same given area.

DFECBDDCE87F4F89B6FF332AA1F79725.description: Construct a rectangle for a given area.

77E2620CDA9F436498AF9F50B7A2D50E.description: Determine the area of an irregular 2-D shape, and explain the strategy.

88B468CFAEAF4E488D382065A8243CAF.description: Determine the area of a regular 2-D shape, and explain the strategy.

DD9934F1C7504FDE9ED7CF7CA3361D8D.description: Estimate the area of a given 2-D shape using personal referents.

08411E9919B94352BC5E0B8BBDD39886.description: Determine which standard square unit is represented by a given referent.

EF93D56D00894DA99736F9A8701F1A29.description: Provide a referent for a square metre, and explain the choice.

DD6A734185704F2992D93629FB92E536.description: Provide a referent for a square centimetre, and explain the choice.

5AFF69FE99D44EE4B7DE43203974EAF2.description: Identify and explain why the square is the most efficient unit for measuring area.

4B9FFD38CE9D4E949A36CC351FEAD074.description: Describe area as the measure of surface recorded in square units.

EF8DECBE53744455873A4B71A1513FEC.description:
Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of area of regular and irregular 2-D shapes by
recognizing that area is measured in square units
selecting and justifying referents for the units square centimetre (cm2) or square metre (m2)
estimating area using referents for cm2 or m2
determining and recording area (cm2 or m2)
constructing different rectangles for a given area (cm2 or m2) in order to demonstrate that many different rectangles may have the same area
[C, CN, ME, PS, R, V]

CD8297AEEF494962B2E178C1A3A2812E.description: Identify possible interpretations of a given date (e.g., 06/03/04).

5EAA8894658041538101002086599695.description: Relate dates written in the format yyyy/mm/dd to dates on a calendar.

6AC1FE0D09C54F97B4FF5E6F65733B21.description: Write dates in a variety of formats (e.g., yyyy/mm/dd, dd/mm/yyyy, March 21, 2014, dd/mm/yy).

555F25E1F2F84878934AF9DA14C699C5.description: Students will be expected to read and record calendar dates in a variety of formats. [C, V]

9AEE42861A384788AF2AC28FF6CAD7DA.description: Explain the meaning of a.m. and p.m., and provide an example of an activity that occurs during the a.m., and another that occurs during the p.m.

52F7F5DAED78484B8C0EAC33C75BE502.description: Describe time orally as “minutes to” or “minutes after” the hour.

1DADD36388854C6FB2C6DCFC946023DB.description: Express time orally and numerically from a 24-hour digital clock.

02883C796A994169961790FC1AEAB321.description: Express the time orally and numerically from a 12-hour digital clock.

6C17893DE8CC48E5A88C248B29701A72.description: Express the time orally and numerically from a 24-hour analog clock.

BD7F40A9231440AF906AF2EFEED00099.description: Express the time orally and numerically from a 12-hour analog clock.

D99C17D5D325425993D7558F5EA36E37.description: State the number of hours in a day.

9FE52D0AE4DD4D23877C78DD01EDA8EB.description: Students will be expected to read and record time using digital and analog clocks, including 24- hour clocks. [C, CN, V]

D8D83C664F6642139A4818AD273B3828.description: Solve equations using a symbol to represent the unknown.

FB01AF095A9E48F39C63E47EB869DD74.description: Represent and solve a given multiplication or division problem involving equal grouping or partitioning (equal sharing) using symbols to represent the unknown.

7E554BA5C52B4358B014845F5A3DCD38.description: Represent and solve a given addition or subtraction problem involving a “part-part-whole” or comparison context using a symbol to represent the unknown.

7AACDADA4C054B3097FD8EB14A0EB30D.description: Solve a given equation when the unknown is on the left or right side of the equation.

34D8510D55C148DE9524E1FEF292CE4E.description: Describe, orally, the meaning of a given one-step equation with one unknown.

5425EBBC40664C4AA8480AA0F703D541.description: Solve a given one-step equation using guess and test.

7535AA267FF340F495B2A51D9AC16E47.description: Represent and solve a given one-step equation concretely, pictorially, or symbolically.

29A93898F00641C4984E169530A2E149.description: Students will be expected to solve one-step equations involving a symbol to represent an unknown number. [C, CN, PS, R, V]

D070AC1B6D964F4ABE230C3F025604B8.description: Create a problem in context for a given equation with one unknown.

B8E3F8D58E3E44A0BECB9374394C7D01.description: Identify the unknown in a problem; represent the problem with an equation; and solve the problem concretely, pictorially, and/or symbolically.

108AFB19BA224DCAA85A22C41C446A2A.description: Express a given pictorial or concrete representation of an equation in symbolic form.

C95CB42DA7B645C091CCC3E32A1585F0.description: Explain the purpose of the symbol in a given addition, subtraction, multiplication, or division equation with one unknown (e.g., 36 ÷ = 6).

DA6AEC78D8E94925A09C30567618170B.description: Students will be expected to express a given problem as an equation in which a symbol is used to represent an unknown number. [CN, PS, R]

2D8394FA5EC746D3A1FB3E8551584F9C.description: Solve a given problem by using a chart or diagram to identify mathematical relationships.

A1779FE60FBB484DB93C8E088216EFED.description: Determine where new elements belong in a given Venn diagram.

EE63723E584E4B34B3A77E69C50669EA.description: Describe the relationship shown in a given Venn diagram when the circles overlap, when one circle is contained in the other, and when the circles are separate.

A95A07CE16A44796A0A3EBD9EA00C6AC.description: Identify a sorting rule for a given Venn diagram.

31DF1A80FA0B441691ECAB8DF1011AA0.description: Solve a given problem using a Carroll diagram.

2746EDF0F6B1470786F78A0D42A5455C.description: Determine where new elements belong is a given Carroll diagram.

A9C7EE995AF1412EA9A0A9E73AA93561.description: Complete a given Carroll diagram to solve a problem.

1F4EFFF44160403D91E310B5ED8029C9.description: Students will be expected to identify and explain mathematical relationships, using charts and diagrams, to solve problems. [CN, PS, R, V]

F7C287A80A79439484AD3CE8F72423FD.description: Identify, describe, and extend the patterns in a table or chart to solve a given problem.

72F440A8B0E74B90982F78214E1D095D.description: Translate the information in a given problem into a table or chart.

40743164E22B49A99B1FC08DC57652FC.description: Students will be expected to represent, describe, and extend patterns and relationships, using charts and tables, to solve problems. [C, CN, PS, R, V]

F388C451825841F5A6FB9C2F64C3F3A4.description: Explain why the same relationship exists between the pattern in a table and its concrete representation.

09886F9B53B342CC86FCA1C1B264AEEA.description: Translate between pictorial, contextual, and concrete representations of a pattern.

E343A698170A468BB9EE9F8A416F217B.description: Create a concrete representation of a given pattern displayed in a table or chart.

76338478998C4557AFA128CCF6F396C4.description: Create a table or chart from a given concrete representation of a pattern.

B8AF9474EE0A447D9F4AB634081800A7.description: Students will be expected to translate among different representations of a pattern (a table, a chart, or concrete materials). [C, CN, V]

F7D72354ECE84A009F929F6A509EC5AF.description: Describe the pattern found in a given table or chart.

DC22D99359B3480CB0F5B7DFCEC9CE8F.description: Identify the error(s) in a given table or chart.

A41249DDCB04404AA073EF39859814D1.description: Determine the missing element(s) in a given table or chart.

317DD5D7B79E4AC3AD0C31C34578EFF3.description: Identify and describe a variety of patterns in a multiplication chart.

5C0E0318F8C840A9AF5FF47D71437D6F.description: Students will be expected to identify and describe patterns found in tables and charts, including a multiplication chart. [C, CN, PS, V]

D25579F26DDB48F69FDC740679022DD8.description: Determine an exact solution using mental computation strategies.

DAB61B7A56584F9BACA2C7C505FC4EEF.description: Count back change for a given purchase.

A6261E85C16743809085F6991F940ECD.description: Determine the approximate solution of a given problem not requiring an exact answer.

3521A2120DBC4E02BEE9B220ACAC0534.description: Ask students to determine which problems do not require an exact solution.

3721FF148DA648F4B80049840D914183.description: Solve problems, including money problems, that involve addition and subtraction of decimals (limited to hundredths), using personal strategies.

B7E2C32AD4A34C35B30B28DE130AFF0C.description: Predict sums and differences of decimals, using estimation strategies.

58C3CE7411DF47CE9EDA77473B739360.description:
Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of addition and subtraction of decimals (limited to hundredths) by
estimating sums and differences
using mental mathematics strategies to solve problems
using personal strategies to determine sums and differences [C, ME, PS, R, V]

1319E1C3168F4F288A4E48D51D83D164.description:
Express, orally and symbolically, the decimal equivalent for a given fraction

(e.g., 50
100

AC6B2312D59043FCAD73BC1F8ADA3887.description: Express a given pictorial or concrete representation as a fraction or decimal (e.g., 15 shaded squares on a hundredth grid can be expressed as 0.15 or 15 ).

C18F8AC16FA447F19D266C7FFC25EFCD.description: Express, orally and symbolically, a given decimal in fraction form.

BF496F3814D143EEA298CFD3D16498BE.description: Read decimals as fractions (e.g., 0.5 is zero and five tenths).

F5445958652642BA8712D701E3AA8E51.description: Express, orally and symbolically, a given fraction with a denominator of 10 or 100 as a decimal.

4A46BE2DF2044F77AB4983A0BC308972.description: Students will be expected to relate decimals to fractions and fractions to decimals (to hundredths). [C, CN, R, V]

1C38DE170F054990BF33CA77D02C36E4.description: Model, using manipulatives or pictures, that a given tenth can be expressed as a hundredth (e.g., 0.9 is equivalent to 0.90, or 9 dimes is equivalent to 90 pennies).

3B4C00FDE2F84D25B601A1D48F9D4572.description: Provide examples of everyday contexts in which tenths and hundredths are used.

EB4E32EAD62946B181169E122AB555B4.description: Record a given money value using decimals.

EC58CFD2F19C4FB181676015F1C8D675.description: Represent a given decimal using money values (dimes and pennies).

1EBB1883B15A40FEA2FFEBB14262BC5F.description: Explain the meaning of each digit in a given decimal.

E4ACD8326E8E48939062DC5F07E61E2C.description: Represent a given decimal using concrete materials or a pictorial representation.

51283D1848134FB281276F4871F636FF.description: Write the decimal for a given concrete or pictorial representation of part of a set, part of a region, or part of a unit of measure.

98356C30908A4798A26E3B7677BE8FE0.description: Students will be expected to describe and represent decimals (tenths and hundredths) concretely, pictorially, and symbolically. [C, CN, R, V]

2B378A680B8F41EB99526B21B146C8E6.description: Provide, from everyday contexts, an example of a fraction that represents part of a set and an example of a fraction that represents part of one whole.

773552F895A14BFA8169E90A8355923C.description: Provide examples of instances when two identical fractions may not represent the same quantity.

9AA65A2E01A345C5A7DC75D634FC4D26.description: Order a given set of fractions by placing them on a number line with given benchmarks.

B74F37C77DFD48E3AAF21E6F0C144F99.description: Name fractions between two given benchmarks on a number line.

13FFEFD80B59483FA431C0534DEA65F0.description: Identify which of the benchmarks 0, 1 , or 1 is closer to a given fraction.

29055A01740041D0BC5629138F96B40B.description: Order a given set of fractions that have the same denominator, and explain the ordering.

D6EB5424265046699FCAFBA40A407789.description: Order a given set of fractions that have the same numerator, and explain the ordering.

6F05874DE532481297D8B3F3CA5C2278.description: Explain how denominators can be used to compare two given unit fractions with a numerator of 1.

7F2CBE56AF05490FB07E34D243BD4957.description: Represent a given fraction pictorially by shading parts of a given whole object, region, or set.

6739797DEA334B03A7E0CC76C43F36CC.description: Name and record the shaded and non-shaded parts of a given whole object, region, or set.

43E55E7B2F894413B24DC626EFCCE986.description: Identify a fraction from its given concrete representation.

308F1E6B219B4EC0B0FB5F310C35222F.description: Represent a given fraction of one whole object, region, or a set using concrete materials.

235AA7BCD14D459F80A0C7E9CA398FF3.description:
Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of fractions less than or equal to 1 by using concrete, pictorial, and symbolic representations to
name and record fractions for the parts of one whole or a set
compare and order fractions
model and explain that for different wholes, two identical fractions may not represent the same quantity
provide examples of where fractions are used [C, CN, PS, R, V]

E69316DCE8EB4CAC9D52D377737C6AE5.description: Solve a given division problem by relating division to multiplication (e.g., for 80 ÷ 4, we know that 4 × 20 = 80, so 80 ÷ 4 = 20).

58DF47EFD3A34E1FB00A3112D9F40BA8.description: Estimate a quotient using a personal strategy (e.g., 86 ÷ 4 is close to 80 ÷ 4 or close to 80 ÷ 5).

7CE029969A2E4E078407BA31B150B04F.description: Create and solve division word problems involving a one- or two-digit dividend, and record the process pictorially and symbolically.

672D69D3971B48F1B9F2F1BDCF792955.description: Solve a given division problem, using a personal strategy, and record the process symbolically.

B81212593AA047899361311D1D5AE923.description: Model the division of two given numbers with a remainder, limited to a one-digit divisor and up to a two-digit dividend, using concrete or visual representations, and record the process pictorially and symbolically. (It is not intended that remainders be expressed as decimals or fractions.)

CDEB5D4321EF4ECDA309E50A9520ED7A.description: Model the division of two given numbers without a remainder, limited to a one-digit divisor and up to a two-digit dividend, using concrete or visual representations, and record the process pictorially and symbolically.

8107B620068B4220AC2E41CCE4493FDE.description:
Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of division (one-digit divisor and up to two-digit dividend) to solve problems by
using personal strategies for dividing, with and without concrete materials
estimating quotients
relating division to multiplication [C, CN, ME, PS, R, V]

D3BDAE11B96B4DFDA8239DF3BFFB54D1.description: Determine the product of two given numbers using a personal strategy, and record the process symbolically.

E156F3BC5F104B8B98D5C5CF2840197F.description: Model and solve a given multiplication problem using an array, and record the process.

7B45D223689D4E4F8AFF0DB501CC4719.description: Estimate a product using a personal strategy (e.g., 2 × 243 is close to or a little more than 2 × 200, or close to or a little less than 2 × 250).

E508ABF207C9490FB29461AD051C448E.description: Create and solve multiplication story problems, limited to one-, two-, or three-digit by one- digit numerals, and record the process symbolically.

8FCEA36D17E54DAD8D19B689B272A059.description: Model the multiplication of two given numbers, limited to one-, two-, or three-digit by one- digit numerals, using concrete or visual representations, and record the process symbolically.

042B61C072064C70BDB95A6237FA4833.description: Model a given multiplication problem, using the distributive property (e.g., 8 × 365 = (8 × 300) + (8 × 60) + (8 × 5)).

26966F6C21DF4EBE82D8E03BBCFB60E2.description:
Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of multiplication (one-, two-, or three-digit by one-digit numerals) to solve problems by
using personal strategies for multiplication, with and without concrete materials
using arrays to represent multiplication
connecting concrete representations to symbolic representations
estimating products
applying the distributive property [C, CN, ME, PS, R, V]

712FA5B31AF94678B8E4B7D60988374A.description: Quickly recall basic multiplication facts up to 9 × 9.

B5996D37A0A4494DA8054C07C4F40D5F.description: Use and describe a personal strategy for determining the division facts.

A44A532F3FA745F9B55DA44B53A55637.description: Use and describe a personal strategy for determining the multiplication facts.

E34DDAD711034B3485BA43B05C0850BC.description: Describe the mental mathematics strategy used to determine basic multiplication or division facts.

4F2BFAF4F71448E3B8DE84849A651FA1.description: Students will be expected to describe and apply mental mathematics strategies, to recall basic multiplication facts to 9 × 9, and to determine related division facts. [C, CN, ME, R]

33CD259AB67F4689B37F3D8F1A242DD3.description: Determine the answer to a given question involving the division of a number by 1, and explain the answer using the property of 1 in division.

882DB362A7704FB5AF3AAB51A791B16F.description: Determine the answer to a given question involving the multiplication of a number by 0, and explain the answer using the property of 0 in multiplication.

0BE299C955C343A5A8E761D421C07D55.description: Determine the answer to a given question involving the multiplication of a number by 1, and explain the answer using the property of 1 in multiplication.

244FAB612A5B4BD9B5E3ACF51498623D.description: Students will be expected to apply and explain the properties of 0 and 1 for multiplication and the property of 1 for division. [C, CN, R]

3C4503D1F2D54AF6A08AF5DC32A2436F.description: Determine a sum or difference of one-, two-, and three-digit numerals efficiently, using mental mathematics strategies.

9A1C0B19DD264DA482196AA880315D49.description: Explain mental mathematics strategies that could be used to determine a sum or difference.

08DA2B0E8E404435B2153AB430CCB09D.description: Create and solve problems that involve addition and subtraction of two or more numbers, limited to three- and four-digit numerals.

9DBFE10676804910A4AC6DE44B60FCC8.description: Estimate sums and differences using different strategies.

2BD2D94CBEAC4734AD179C34B4395B40.description: Describe a situation in which an estimate rather than an exact answer is sufficient.

A1A2A3F5F72F418A869C53BB67FA8BC2.description: Determine the difference of two given numbers, limited to three- and four-digit numerals, using a personal strategy, and record the process symbolically.

D48F3DD43E884D488777013B44ABB592.description: Determine the sum of two given numbers, limited to three- and four-digit numerals, using a personal strategy, and record the process symbolically.

BE4BCB1FBE5D4433AEE6DB7C9D6452AA.description: Represent concretely, pictorially, and symbolically the addition and subtraction of whole numbers, limited to three- and four-digit numerals.

D1F757E6B5F1411C8989DB0A3DF368A3.description:
Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of addition and subtraction of numbers with answers to 10 000 (limited to three- and four-digit numerals) by
using personal strategies for adding and subtracting
estimating sums and differences
solving problems involving addition and subtraction [C, CN, ME, PS, R]

472A479602FB401C8F253DB6B99FA251.description: Compare numbers based on a variety of methods.

577451ED6DEA4727807509D85A1E942E.description: Place numbers on a number line containing benchmark numbers for the purpose of comparison.

94CB1DE6962049FFBCECAFE8C7778C82.description: Place numbers in relative order on an open number line.

DBB464825E40416F9CEC891DA02EA99A.description: Identify incorrectly placed numbers in an ordered sequence and on a number line.

1D46BB8D11B64827B8455C8134C8521B.description: Identify the missing numbers in an ordered sequence and on a number line.

AA1060CD946F45EC81E26A2C5E9CDDDF.description: Create and order three different four-digit numerals.

0488BBA164EC4B71A3F6E1896240F5F0.description: Order a given set of numbers in ascending or descending order, and explain the order by making references to place value.

1F56AFBD1164473EBD8FD6F7FFCA0CAE.description: Students will be expected to compare and order numbers to 10 000. [C, CN, V]

E4B5BCFAB6104048A798291153B96A2F.description: Represent a given number using expressions.

B7D65CFA154D43A1A600D9E4A5405991.description: Read a given number word, 0 to 10 000.

A21B99C9B6454DD3A27443467F4368EB.description: Represent a given number in a variety of ways and explain how they are equivalent.

6B1BBEEF766242F1AB86A25C29132C9F.description: Explain the meaning of each digit in a given four-digit numeral.

5062D9A58D094CB5AA542D4C3E6E940A.description: Write the numeral represented by a given expanded notation.

99C91DE4A04B45CA962EBB71EFD09173.description: Express a given numeral in expanded notation (e.g., 4321 = 4000 + 300 + 20 + 1).

E467EE34393049F591AFFF5AB9A27854.description: Represent a given numeral using a place-value chart or diagrams.

C6AA780A704F45B588E1A454F2C0BE2C.description: Write a given numeral, 0 to 10 000, in words.

96820ECBBF1A43A9A37F59B2DFA5A9D9.description: Record numerals for numbers expressed orally, concretely, pictorially, and/or symbolically as expressions, using proper spacing without commas.

403C381BF795465BB92C9269D43441D4.description: Read a given four-digit numeral without using the word “and.”

4CBB706508E04DED975BF76F439DC004.description: Students will be expected to represent and partition whole numbers to 10 000. [C, CN, V]
